Award.AwardTitle: Dissertation Research: Eco-Evolutionary Dynamics of the Dilution Effect
Award.AbstractNarration:
One surprising effect of biological diversity can be to reduce the spread of disease: infection of one host species may be lower in the presence of other host species. This ?dilution effect? is typically seen when the species are similar enough that they compete for resources such as food. The net effect of species diversity then depends on whether diversity reduces infection more than it decreases the availability of resources. This project will investigate the dilution effect using artificial communities of two zooplankton, algae they both eat, and a fungus that infects one of the zooplankton more readily than the other. Previous work with these communities showed that the net effect of the less susceptible zooplankton on the more susceptible one depended on genetic diversity: the higher the genetic diversity of the more susceptible zooplankton, the more beneficial the presence of the less susceptible one. This suggests that rapid evolution of the susceptible zooplankton was required for the dilution effect to operate. Research will now measure how the genetic makeup of the susceptible zooplankton changes as competition and infection proceed, and how the genetic changes result in changes in the traits of the zooplankton to create a dilution effect. Results should increase understanding both of how ecology and evolution can affect each other and how biodiversity can counter disease.

The broader impacts of this research include applications to control of disease in wildlife and in humans. Dilution effects may be important in serious diseases such as Lyme disease, West Nile virus, Hantavirus, and schistosomiasis. The project will also provide research experience for undergraduate researchers including members of underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project merges two exciting fields in the ecology and evolution of disease: diversity-disease relationships (i.e., dilution effects) and eco-evolutionary dynamics. The dilution effect suggests that conservation of biodiversity could regulate disease, because ‘diluter’ species interfere with disease transmission in diverse communities. If dilution effects lower densities of infected wildlife hosts, they could shield humans from zoonoses including schistosomiasis, hantavirus, and Lyme disease. Diverse communities might also protect charismatic wildlife from threatening emergent diseases, like the frog-killing chytrid fungus. From this perspective, dilution effects offer a tantalizing win-win for conservation of species diversity and regulation of disease. Yet diluter taxa frequently compete with focal hosts for resources. In fact, the combination of virulent disease and competition with diluters can strongly depress the densities of hosts – despite the potential for a dilution effect – and maybe even drive focal hosts extinct. In the core experiment of this project, we see such an outcome in a mesocosm experiment featuring planktonic hosts… at least when we constrain the evolutionary potential of the host population. 

In contrast, when we allowed hosts to rapidly evolve in response to competitor- and parasite-mediated selection, these outcomes changed. Evolution is frequently assumed to operate on much slower time scales than ecological interactions like disease transmission and dilution. However, sufficiently rapid evolution can change host traits and feed back to modulate contemporaneous ecological dynamics. We see such ‘eco-evolutionary dynamics’ in our core experiment. Parasites (and to a lesser extent, diluters) catalyzed the rapid evolution of enhanced competitive ability in genetically diverse host populations. In turn, enhanced competitive ability buffered the densities of these host populations from the negative impacts of competition and disease. Despite this evolutionary rescue, diluters still reduced the density of infected hosts. In other words, we detected dilution effects both when hosts were evolutionarily constrained and when they rapidly evolved. However, these eco-evolutionary dynamics also heralded a darker outcome: host populations that evolved enhanced competitive ability and maintained robust densities also supported higher densities of infections. Thus, rapid evolution rescued host densities, but also unleashed larger epidemics. 

Outcomes of this project suggests several implications for species conservation and human health. Genetic diversity is clearly important for maintaining robust populations of hosts, especially when they suffer epidemics or compete with other species. Then again, genetically diverse populations could ultimately fuel larger epidemics, depending on how parasite- and/or competitor-mediated selection shapes traits of the host population. Our results also confirm that the addition of 'diluter' taxa can reduce disease. Nevertheless, the impact of diluters on disease depends on host traits like competitive ability and resistance to disease. Adding the 'wrong' diluter species to a community could drive focal hosts extinct, even if it did reduce disease. Such an outcome could seem especially undesirable from a perspective focused on conservation of focal hosts. Then again, extinction of wildlife hosts may seem like a favorable outcome, if those wildlife hosts could transmit dangerous zoonoses – including Lyme disease, hantavirus, and schistosomiasis - to humans. Thus, both dilution effects and eco-evolutionary dynamics have the potential to influence conservation and human health. Our project strengthens foundations for predicting such impacts.

Our core results have also inspired a number of complementary analyses that further grapple with this exciting intersection of disease ecology and eco-evolutionary dynamics. One complementary experiment delineates the traits of hosts that predict the size of epidemics in communities with diluters. Epidemics are smaller when hosts resist infection but compete weakly (which allows diluters to become more numerous). A complementary analysis of our core experiment quantifies the impact of rapid evolution on the strength of interactions among hosts, parasites, and diluters. These interactions are severely costly when focal hosts cannot evolve, but become dampened by eco-evolutionary feedbacks. Finally, mathematical theory has begun to explain when epidemics can accelerate the evolution of competitive ability - even when it comes at the cost of lower resistance to disease. Results of all of these analyses have been presented at national conferences, and manuscripts describing two of them have been reviewed by scientific journals. All will soon be published in peer-reviewed journals.

This project has stimulated the research careers of three graduate students and introduced many undergraduates to research experiences. Two graduate students (ATS and JLH) completed their dissertations with support from this grant. They have since both secured postdoctoral positions to ask similar questions. A third graduate student (JMW) continues to pursue analyses inspired by this project for his dissertation. Numerous undergraduates working in the Hall lab from 2014-2016 also contributed to the products of this grant. Thus, this project has impacted numerous young scientists’ careers and continues to inspire exciting questions at the frontier of eco-evolutionary theory for disease.
